title: The Art of Waiting Well
devotional:
Eliza tapped her foot, the rhythmic sound a counterpoint to the ticking clock in the doctor's waiting room. Her son, Caleb, was undergoing tests. A myriad of unknowns hung in the air, each one a small, prickly burr clinging to her anxieties. The doctor was delayed. Each minute stretched into an eternity. She gripped the worn edges of a magazine, the colorful images blurring into a senseless kaleidoscope. 

Eliza had prayed. She'd pleaded. She'd even bargained, a tactic she knew was flawed but felt powerless to resist. Yet, the waiting continued. It felt like an active resistance, a deliberate withholding of answers. The 'what ifs' began to swirl like a dust devil in her mind, each one more terrifying than the last. What if it was serious? What if he needed extensive treatment? What if…

In those moments, Eliza felt the gnawing impatience that so often defined her interactions with the world. She wanted answers, solutions, resolutions – now. It was in that struggle that the Holy Spirit nudged her heart. She remembered the verse, 'Be still, and know that I am God.' Psalm 46:10. Stillness. An active choice to cease striving, to cease demanding, and to rest in the sovereign power and perfect timing of God. 

Patience isn't passive resignation. It is not an empty void where we simply wait and do nothing. Instead, patience is an active trust, a confident expectation that God is at work, even when we cannot see Him. It's believing that His plans are good, even when they don't align with our own. Patience trusts that God is weaving a tapestry of grace and purpose, and that what looks like tangled threads from our perspective is actually a beautiful design in His hands. During this time, she was reminded of her own spiritual journey; it has been one of waiting and developing character. Like training for a marathon, strengthening one's faith takes continuous work and building patience one day at a time. 

Caleb was fine. The doctor came and assured her it was nothing serious. Eliza left the office with a lighter heart, not just because of Caleb's health, but because she had learned a deeper lesson that day: Patience isn't just about waiting; it's about trusting the One who holds all things together. It's about finding peace in the process, knowing that He is working all things for good, in His time, and in His way.
image_description: A close-up of an analog clock with the hands slowly moving, framed by a blurred and out-of-focus waiting room setting.
insights: The Bible is filled with examples of individuals who demonstrated extraordinary patience in the face of adversity. Job, who endured immense suffering, declared, 'Though he slay me, yet will I hope in him' (Job 13:15). Abraham waited years for the promised son, Isaac. The apostle Paul encouraged believers to 'be patient in tribulation' (Romans 12:12). James 5:7-8 exhorts us to 'Be patient, therefore, brothers, until the coming of the Lord... You also, be patient. Establish your hearts, for the coming of the Lord is at hand.' Patience isn't merely a virtue; it's a demonstration of faith in action.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that patience is often a struggle for me. I live in a world that demands instant gratification, and I find it difficult to wait on Your timing. Teach me to trust in Your perfect plan, even when I don't understand it. Help me to find peace in the waiting and to use these times of uncertainty to draw closer to You. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may be patient with others, as You are patient with me. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life are you currently struggling with patience? What steps can you take to cultivate a greater sense of trust in God's timing? How can you actively practice patience towards others, reflecting the grace and mercy that God has shown you?
